Explore (Digging In)

Providing for Individual Needs

  • Students may be able to make sense of many statements. Every student does not need to understand every statement at this time. Use questions to push their thinking. Then, take note of which types of comparison statements students will need to revisit and make sense of as you progress through the unit.
  • Considerations for each statement: As students discuss the statements in their groups, you can ask questions to hep students analyze the statements. (Problem- Solving Environment)
  • Markus's statement is an additive statement. This is not ratio thinking, becasue there is not a multiplicative comparison between two quantities.

Suggested Questions

  • How many quantities are in Markus's statement? How did he get it?
  • If we did not know the goals of the two schools, would the $150 amount tell you anything about how the goals compare to each other?

• One. He subtracted or added on from Academy to Central.
  • Only that one school's goal is larger than the other. The goals could be $1 and $151. Or they could be $1,000 to $1,150

Tabia's statement is a ratio using the "for every" language. Students might find Tabia's more difficult than other statements because the quantities are scaled down. It is not essential that students make sense of this statement until later in the unit.

  • What are the goals of Academy and Central?
  • If each school got double their goal, how much would they have?
  • How do these amounts relate to Tabia's statement?

• Academy: $300 and Central: $450
  • Academy: $600 and Central $900
  • Answers will vary. Some students might see that the doubles goal is 10 times the amounts in Tabia's statement.)
